author: EMMA BLAKE
title: Why it’s worth packing a travel money card
text:
Kristen Smits packed a travel card to keep her finances safe while in Europe.
EMMA BLAKE THE dollar may be diving but our love of international travel continues.
While you can’t control exchange rates, you can plan how you’re going to pay for things while overseas.
If you don’t, you could end up getting caught short at the worst possible time, paying excessive fees, or being burned by negative currency movements.
Carrying large amounts of cash is not safe and credit and debit cards can attract unfavourable exchange rates and huge fees from your bank and the international bank where you are withdrawing cash.
Travel money cards are an increasingly popular option
These are prepaid cards, similar to domestic credit/debit cards, that can be loaded with a number of different foreign currencies before you travel.
They’re more secure than cash and have lower fees for accessing your money overseas than a regular card.
Plus, they let you lock in an exchange rate ahead of time so you don’t have to worry about currency movements.
Travel money cards can be loaded with a number of different currencies before you travel. Source: Supplied
Administrator Kristen Smits says she already had a Qantas frequent flyer card which was also a travel money card before she went on her six week trip to Europe.
“I had never used it as a travel card before but while researching travel cards on the internet the Qantas Cash card was one of the top cards recommended and as it gave me frequent flyer points on purchases that was an added bonus,” says Smits.
Mitchell Watson from comparison site Canstar says more than 26,000 people have researched travel money cards on their site over the past three months.
“The three most important features they are looking for are no reload fees, same day reload functionality and the ability to access their money through an ATM,” he says.
The Qantas card is one of the more competitive with no initial card fee, no charge for reloading and competitive ATM fees and exchange rates.
“While the travel money card is a purpose built product for travelling, credit cards are still popular among travelling Australians. We have on average 4,000 people per month searching for a credit cards with travel insurance,” he says.
 Play your travel cards right
